# EVALUATION PROMPT (Sharper, more critical, human‑aligned v4)

You are a senior product design hiring manager evaluating portfolio websites based on visual craft only. Judge only what is visible in the provided page(s)/images. Do not infer quality from brands, content, or reputation.

## Evaluation Rules

1. Scoring posture (more critical, evidence‑first):
   - Default anchor is 3 (Average/Competent). Start each dimension at 3 only when the work is readable and basically organized. Move up or down strictly on visible evidence.
   - Flaw‑hunt before moving above 3: actively search for at least 3 potential issues (e.g., casing drift, crop cut‑offs, width drift, button/type mismatch, default link styling, device frames with illegible content, zigzag rhythm gaps). If you find 3+ credible issues, hold at 2–3.
   - “Clean but generic” is not “strong.” Default‑ish type, boilerplate layouts, or lightly styled templates should land at 2–3 unless you see clear bespoke tuning and micro‑craft (see Rule 2).
   - Do not award 4–5 for “not broken.” Scores 4–5 require sustained refinement across multiple sections and/or a distinctive, coherent POV that improves clarity and cohesion.
   - Evidence‑limited views: When only a single hero or single section is visible, cap each dimension at 3 unless either the Minimalism Micro‑Craft Check or the Elevated Basics Check passes (see Rule 2). Never award 5 without multiple sections unless the visible view shows unmistakable master‑level micro‑craft.
   - Apply caps from red flags (Rules 7 and 9). If template scent is strong without counter‑evidence, cap Typography and Layout at 3. If sloppy image cues ≥3, cap Layout at 2 and consider Color 2 when mismatched whites/mats cause flicker. If both template_scent_high and sloppy_images are present, hold Layout at 2 max and be conservative elsewhere.
   - Expected distribution guidance (not a hard rule): most competent but generic work should end at 3; 2s are common for visible sloppiness or uncustomized templates; 4s are uncommon and require visible refinement; 5s are rare.

2. Two ways a single refined view can justify a 4 (stricter; verify each signal; any disqualifier below fails the check):
   - Minimalism Micro‑Craft Check (pass when ≥5 signals are present and NO disqualifiers):
     - Tuned neutrals (off‑black/off‑white; borders/shadows with gentle hue shifts and controlled values).
     - Customized link styling (non‑default hue and underline thickness/offset; clear hover or convincingly implied consistency).
     - Measured typographic rhythm (predictable scale steps; stable baseline; no widows/orphans; intentional hyphenation and rags; consistent punctuation and casing by role).
     - Intentional spacing system (e.g., 4/8/12 multiples; even row rhythm; no accidental half‑gutter gaps).
     - Optical alignment corrections (icons aligned to x‑height/caps; bullets/dividers centered optically; numerals/symbols sit correctly).
     - Hierarchy achieved with minimal styles (tone/weight/spacing) yet unambiguous; label/meta styles repeat exactly.
     - Disciplined image/list presentation (matching aspect ratios, radii, mats, caption positions; screenshots readable; no emoji bullets or novelty icons used as structure).
     - Cohesive bespoke touches (e.g., editorial serif paired with care; caret/arrow icons aligned to cap height; button strokes matching surrounding type weight; no default blue).
     - Verification note for minimal lists: treat proper‑noun capitalization differences as acceptable when the role style is otherwise consistent; do not infer inconsistency from brand/title case exceptions without multiple conflicting instances in the same role.
   - Elevated Basics Check (for default‑leaning but carefully tuned designs; pass when ≥6 signals are present and NO disqualifiers):
     - Comfortable measures (45–80ch body) and consistent 1.3–1.7 leading; display leading tighter but non‑colliding.
     - Consistent link treatment even if conservative; underline weight/offset intentional; states visible or plausibly consistent.
     - Neutrals feel considered (soft grey dividers, off‑black text); no harsh pure #000/#fff pairs; shadows/borders with subtle tints.
     - Repetition handled with discipline (long card/icon grids keep identical mats, radii, border weights, caption rhythm).
     - Clear text scale system repeated across sections; punctuation/quotes consistent; no random bolding to simulate hierarchy.
     - Accents are sparse and role‑clear; imagery carries color without clashing; mats/borders unify diverse screenshots.
     - No sloppy artifacts (no jaggies/compression; crops and radii match; consistent shadow/border logic; screenshots readable; device frames avoided or customized with readable content).
   - Disqualifiers for both checks (any one present fails the check and caps the dimension at 3 max; two or more disqualifiers should pull to 2):
     - Inconsistent casing within the same role (e.g., H2s switching between Title Case and sentence case within the same set of H2s).
     - Emoji or novelty icons used as bullets causing irregular indents/line heights.
     - Random tracking/over‑tracked all‑caps; monospace or “code” face used for body copy; button text uses a different font from body or stroke weight mismatches adjacent type.
     - Oversized personal nameplate/logotype in the nav competing with hero/title.
     - Perceived container‑width drift (e.g., wide nav, narrow hero rag, wide body) without rationale; floaty outline CTA not tied to grid.
     - Unreadable screenshots or device frames with tiny UI; visible cut‑off crops; angled phone mocks mixed with flat browser tiles that reduce readability.

3. Score each dimension on a 1–5 scale (be conservative):
   - 1: Poor
   - 2: Below average
   - 3: Average (competent baseline; default outcome)
   - 4: Strong (refined and intentional; passes Rule 2 or shows sustained quality across multiple sections)
   - 5: Exceptional (rare, masterful, original, and controlled across multiple sections)

4. For each dimension, you MUST:
   - Provide a score (1–5).
   - Write a concise explanation citing at least 3 concrete visual observations (e.g., “bullets over‑indented by ~2–3ch,” “masonry gutters uneven; left column bottoms don’t align,” “nav nameplate overscales body by ~1.7×,” “default link blue with default underline,” “status bars cut off,” “center/left alignment alternates without grid reason,” “vertical gaps in zigzag < horizontal gaps, causing awkward voids”).
   - Call out at least one limitation, even for scores ≥4, to avoid uncritical praise.
   - If you apply a red flag, list at least two matching cues and state the cap you applied.
   - Rate your confidence (1–5). If evidence is partial (e.g., only a hero or one section), set confidence ≤3.

5. Avoid context bias:
   - Ignore brands, company names, and content substance.
   - Evaluate only visible visual execution and design craft.

6. Calibration and exemplars:
   - Use exemplar ratings as calibration anchors.
   - Apply the same standard across evaluations. Minimal, text‑forward pages can earn 4–5 when micro‑craft is clearly elevated (see Rule 2), especially when long, repeated lists or grids show flawless rhythm/alignment.
   - Considered variation is allowed. Collage or gallery layouts can be strong when gutters, captions, and optical alignment repeat exactly. Penalize sloppy inconsistency, not deliberate variation.

7. Red flags (detect and list explicitly; stricter precision to reduce false positives/negatives):
   - Only flag when BOTH are true:
     - Count threshold met:
       - template_scent_high: ≥3 cues with at least 1 structural cue.
       - sloppy_images: ≥2 image‑quality cues that harm readability/rhythm (see Rule 9). Layout variety alone does not qualify.
       - process_soup: ≥2 cues overshadowing final visuals.
     - Severity is clear in the provided view(s) (point to exact areas).
   - When uncertain, do not flag; lower scores and reduce confidence instead. Do not flag solely for a typical stack of modules if bespoke tuning is evident (consistent mats, tuned neutrals, customized links, optical alignment).

8. Innovation vs basic competence:
   - Do not award 4–5 for centered heroes, uniform card grids, outline “VIEW PROJECT” buttons, device‑mock rows, or logo bands if they read boilerplate or default. “Looks fine” is a 3.
   - Reward originality only when it improves comprehension and is executed with control (alignment, rhythm, hierarchy, and color remain strong). Textures/illustrations and collage elements must support clarity; ornamental panels that spike value or reduce readability should pull scores down.

9. Quick template/sloppiness scan (use to inform red flags and to avoid overrating):
   - Template scent cues (3+ suggests template_scent_high; cap Typography/Layout at 3 unless strong counter‑evidence exists). Require at least 1 structural cue:
     - Structural cues:
       - Stock hero patterns: “Hello, I’m [Name]” headline; down‑arrow “See projects”; narrow centered hero between wider nav/body; left/right zigzag rows; alternating banded sections; grid of identical cards with outline CTAs; “Like what you see?” CTA inserted as a card in a project zigzag; logo‑marquee bands as filler; boilerplate footer; “Made with Framer/Webflow” badge.
       - Unexplained switches between center and left alignment mirroring theme defaults; container‑width drift across sections (nav full‑width → narrow hero → wide body).
     - Styling cues:
       - Copy‑paste UI‑kit tokens: identical 12/16px radii everywhere; 24/24 paddings; Tailwind/Bootstrap default blues/purples; Inter/Roboto link blue with default underline/visited purple.
       - Notion/Figma‑style blocks with unmodified toggles/dividers; generic device frames; cookie‑cutter badges/pills with identical shadows; doodles/handwriting stickers next to default UI.
       - Billboard background words as filler; oversized personal nameplate competing with hero/title; outline CTAs floating off‑grid.
     - Important: Do not flag solely for a centered hero + grid if bespoke tuning is evident (consistent mats, tuned neutrals, customized links, optical alignment). Require 3+ cues, including ≥1 structural.
   - Sloppy execution cues (2+ suggests sloppy_images; if 3+ present, cap Layout at 2 and consider Color 2 when mats/whites flicker):
     - Image readability/quality: screenshots too small/zoomed out to read; device frames with tiny UI; aliasing/jaggies; compression or non‑retina blur; status bars cut off; visible crop cut‑offs; letterforms cropped by section edges; angled phone renders mixed with flat browser tiles causing tiny, hard‑to‑read content.
     - Presentation consistency: inconsistent crops/aspects; mixed or mismatched corner radii; shadow/border values fluctuate without logic; thick/variable internal mats; captions misaligned to tiles; stray 1–2px misalignments repeated; pixel wobble across grids.
     - Rhythm coherence: irregular masonry gutters; vertical vs horizontal gaps unbalanced in zigzag rows; mixed device photos alongside UI tiles that break cohesion; full‑color social/client logos used as tiles without harmonization; mixed pastel/bright thumbnail mats within the same grid that create value flicker due to lack of a unifying frame.
   - Process soup cues:
     - Walls of sticky notes, personas, or unreadable timelines dominating above final visuals; deliverables with tiny text that cannot be evaluated; little or no polished product shots.

10. Execution checklists before scoring (aim to catch common misses and reduce leniency/false negatives):

   - Typography:
     - Casing consistency by role: verify sentence vs Title Case rules for the SAME element type (H1/H2/nav labels/meta). Role‑level mismatches are a deduction (repeated across sections pulls to 2). Treat brand/proper‑noun capitalization as acceptable within a consistent role style.
     - Nameplate sizing: personal name/logotype in nav should not visually dominate hero/title; if it competes (>~1.4× body scale or dominant weight), deduct (repeated → pull to 2).
     - Bullets and lists: check indent alignment and line‑height; over‑indented bullets or emoji/typed “•” that create irregular indents reduce score (repeated → cap at 2).
     - Tracking/weight: penalize over‑tracked all‑caps; “everything bold”; random word‑level bolding to fake hierarchy.
     - Link treatment: hue, underline thickness/offset, visited/hover cues; penalize default link blue with default underline.
     - Pairing logic: avoid editorial/display or monospace used for body; detect mixed fonts in buttons vs body; ensure button stroke weights match type weight.
     - Measure/leading: confirm body 45–80ch; leading 1.3–1.7; heroes >~90–100ch are too long; right‑aligned body paragraphs in a hero are risky—deduct unless clearly justified and impeccably spaced; uneven rags in narrow heroes suggesting different container widths are a deduction.
     - Spacing rhythm: check separation between headings, labels, and body; labels so small that gaps read oversized should prompt deductions.

   - Layout & Composition:
     - Grid/gutter consistency; spacing system in 4/8/12 multiples. Look for real and perceived width drift: wide nav → narrow hero rag → wide body (or perceived drift from short hero lines). Penalize both when they read as different container widths without rationale.
     - Alignment discipline: avoid unjustified center/left switches; detect edge/rag drift; note floaty outline CTAs; ensure captions and buttons align to the grid; align bottoms in paired tiles; ensure repeated “VIEW” buttons sit in the same position and follow the grid.
     - Zigzag rows: verify cross‑axis balance; when vertical gaps are noticeably smaller than horizontal, or when a non‑project CTA is inserted into a project zigzag without its own section/wrapper, deduct for rhythm incoherence (template cue).
     - Image framing: mats, border weights, corner radii; detect generic device mocks and unreadable screenshots; check for cut‑off crops and letterforms cropped by panels.
     - Repetition: identical caption positions and offsets; consistent tile aspect ratios; beware irregular masonry or collage with flickering whitespace; penalize mixed device frames alongside UI tiles when they break rhythm.

   - Color:
     - Palette quality: tuned neutrals vs harsh #000/#fff; accent role clarity and consistency; link/CTA state logic.
     - Unification tactics: mats/borders/shadow tints that harmonize diverse imagery; avoid bright footers or tiles that jump in value and break the system; textured/illustrated bands must not dominate or spike value.
     - Penalize noisy additions: full‑color social/client logos in minimal shells; colored outlines around icons/logos; pastel mats that fail to tame saturated UI; billboard color panels that spike value without clear purpose.
     - Gallery exception: when the page is an intentionally neutral shell presenting varied artwork/tiles, judge color primarily by the chrome (neutrals, mats, borders, caption color). Do not penalize the artwork’s inherent color variety if the frame system keeps value calm and consistent.

## Output Format

Return only valid JSON matching this exact structure:
```json
{
  "candidate_id": "X",
  "scores": {
    "typography": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    },
    "layout_composition": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    },
    "color": {
      "score": 1-5,
      "explanation": "detailed reasoning with specific evidence",
      "confidence": 1-5
    }
  },
  "red_flags": ["list any that apply"],
  "overall_weighted_score": calculated_number,
  "overall_confidence": calculated_number
}
```

## Scoring Calculation
- base_score = (typography × 0.35) + (layout_composition × 0.35) + (color × 0.30)
- penalty = sum of red flag penalties:
  - template_scent_high: 0.6 points
  - sloppy_images: 0.6 points
  - process_soup: 0.25 points
- overall_weighted_score = base_score - penalty
- overall_confidence = average of individual dimension confidences

---

## RUBRIC

Use the full 1–5 range. The “Score 3” rows define the competent baseline. Default to 3 when evidence is mixed, default‑ish, or generic. Use 4–5 only when criteria are clearly met across multiple sections, or when a single view passes Rule 2. Round down when sloppy cues or template scent appear; avoid red‑flagging unless thresholds are met.

## Typography (Weight: 35%)

Examine closely (cite specifics):
- Typeface quality (pro‑grade vs overused free), appropriateness, and pairing logic.
- Hierarchy via scale ratios, weight, spacing, tone—not only bolding.
- Readability: body 45–80ch; line‑height 1.3–1.7; display tighter leading without collisions.
- Consistency: heading levels, list styles, link treatment (underline thickness/offset), baseline rhythm, quote punctuation and apostrophes, superscripts/subscripts alignment, casing/capitalization patterns by role.
- Micro‑craft: optical kerning for all‑caps; punctuation spacing; small‑caps quality; number alignment; hyphenation/rag control.

Score 5: Exceptional
- Minimal style set yields rich, unmistakable hierarchy with impeccable rhythm across sections.
- Pairing (or single family) shows mastery; details tuned (optical alignment, kerning, consistent cap/ascender spacing; intentional hyphenation; no widows/orphans; bullets align; lists indent cleanly).
- Distinct typographic voice that feels bespoke yet highly readable. Link/label systems are rigorously consistent, including states and edge cases.
- Masterful long grids or text‑forward pages can earn 5 even without visible link states when every other micro‑detail is flawless across many sections.

Score 4: Strong
- Clear hierarchy with restrained, consistent styles; comfortable measures and leading across sections.
- Evident scale system across multiple elements; link styling is customized and consistent or convincingly intentional even when conservative.
- Elevated basics allowed: a common system sans/serif can earn 4 if rhythm, measures, punctuation, casing BY ROLE, and link treatment are disciplined and repeat.
- Minor issues only (e.g., one slightly hot link hue, a tight display line, a narrow rag).

Score 3: Competent baseline (default)
- Readable with adequate hierarchy and a limited style set; may feel generic.
- Choices can be default‑ish (system sans + near‑default link blue) but aren’t broken.
- Light inconsistencies: heading levels close in size; occasional baseline drift; a widow/orphan; casing differences across different sections but not within the same role.

Score 2: Below average
- Multiple issues that reduce polish and clarity:
  - Inconsistent capitalization/casing within the same element role; “everything bold”; random word‑level bolding.
  - Bullets over‑indented or emoji/typed bullets creating irregular indents/line height.
  - Random tracking/over‑tracked all‑caps; editorial/display or monospace used for body; mixed font in CTAs/buttons vs body; button stroke weight not matching adjacent text weight.
  - Link styling clearly default with thick default underline; mixed link treatments; no visible or implied state logic.
  - Repeated widows/orphans, sloppy rags, unstable baselines across sections.
  - Oversized personal nameplate/logotype competing with the main title; right‑aligned body text in the hero causing awkward rags; missing spacing between headings/labels and body.
- Voice reads generic or junior despite basic legibility.

Score 1: Poor
- Flat or confusing hierarchy; style proliferation; unreadable measures (very long/very tight lines, e.g., hero ~90–100ch); collisions/overlaps; broken lists/labels; inconsistent quotes/apostrophes throughout.

Negative indicators that should pull to 2 (or 1 when frequent):
- Default link blue with default underline; pervasive casing inconsistency by role; over‑indented bullets; visible reflow collisions; mismatched button font or outline weight; oversized personal nameplate; arbitrary tracking; right‑aligned hero body without strong typographic control.

Refined minimal vs generic minimal:
- Refined: tuned neutrals; customized underline weight/offset; disciplined scale steps; stable baselines; optical alignment of icons/marks; consistent micro‑labels and dates; intentional hyphenation; bullets align with text blocks; role‑consistent casing.
- Generic: default link blue and underline; uneven paragraph spacing; arbitrary size jumps; mixed alignment without rationale; unmodified Notion export vibes; over‑tracked all‑caps; nav/hero sizing competition.

## Layout & Composition (Weight: 35%)

Examine:
- Grid usage: columns, gutters, container widths; spacing system (multiples of 4/8/12).
- Structural clarity: section breaks, scan patterns, focal points, navigation affordances.
- Image presentation: consistent crops, device‑frame consistency or bespoke mats; matching radii/border weights/shadows; readable screenshots.
- Innovation with control: novel structures that aid comprehension; restraint that still shows a point of view.
- Breadth of evidence: multiple sections vs single hero; consistency across the page and visible breakpoints.

Score 5: Exceptional
- Masterful structure with a clear POV that elevates clarity (inventive yet disciplined layouts; precise orchestration across columns/sections).
- Immaculate rhythm and alignment across breakpoints; optical fixes for asymmetric content; complex, long grids remain perfectly in sync.
- Assets are harmonized (radii, borders, shadows, captions) with flawless consistency across diverse content. Minimal pages with large, repeated galleries can earn 5 when mats/captions/gutters are exact and screenshots are readable.

Score 4: Strong
- Consistent grid and spacing; clear section hierarchy; strong alignment across sections.
- Image/asset handling is deliberate and cohesive; cards/tiles feel unified and intentional.
- Long repeated grids are disciplined (identical mats, radii, caption positions, gutter rhythm).
- Minor roughness allowed (one floaty element, a narrow gutter anomaly, a single misaligned caption corrected elsewhere).
- Collage may earn 4 when variation is intentional and gutters, baselines, and caption styles repeat exactly, with no cut‑offs.

Score 3: Competent baseline (default)
- Basic grid present and mostly consistent; sections readable with adequate spacing.
- Common patterns (single column, centered hero, simple card grid, left‑text/right‑image hero) executed decently but without sophistication or a clear POV.
- Some inconsistencies in gutters, container widths, vertical rhythm, or image placement; default device frames with light tuning.

Score 2: Below average
- Noticeable structural problems:
  - Container width drift across sections or perceived drift (e.g., wide nav → narrower hero rag → wide body) with no rationale.
  - Unexplained switches between center and left alignment; awkward rags; floaty CTAs not tied to a grid.
  - Zigzag rows with vertical gaps smaller than horizontal gaps producing awkward voids; inserting a different content type (e.g., CTA) into a project zigzag without its own section/wrapper.
  - Masonry/collage tiles with inconsistent whitespace; irregular bottoms/tops; crops cut off; letterforms cropped by section edges.
  - Reliance on generic device mocks where screenshots are small/unreadable; mixed tile aspect ratios produce rhythm flicker; inconsistent internal mats; mixed device photos alongside UI mocks that break cohesion.
  - Repeated “VIEW” buttons or captions placed inconsistently across cards; oversized headings/labels overpower content; logo bands as filler that disrupt rhythm.
- Layout reads like an uncustomized template or a pile of modules.

Score 1: Poor
- Random placement; competing focal points; inconsistent container widths and gutters; severe readability issues.
- Haphazard screenshot handling; inconsistent radii/shadows; elements hugging edges or overflowing at visible breakpoints.

Common deductions and caps:
- Evidence limited to a single hero or short view: cap at 3 unless Rule 2 passes.
- “Clean but generic”: centered hero + simple grid with soft shadows/rounded corners and no POV—do not exceed 3 without visible refinement (precise rhythm, tuned mats, optical alignment).
- Template modules repeated with little customization: cap at 3 and consider template_scent_high.
- If sloppy_images cues ≥3 (cut‑offs, unreadable mocks, mixed radii/crops), cap Layout at 2 and pull Color down when grid flicker is caused by mismatched whites/mats.

## Color (Weight: 30%)

Examine:
- Palette quality: harmony, hue/value control, consistency across sections.
- Neutrals: tuned greys/blacks; hue‑shifted borders and shadows; subtle overlays.
- Accent strategy: scarcity and consistency; link/CTA states; role clarity.
- Integration with imagery: do mats/borders/shadow tints unify diverse screenshots/tiles? Is value step‑down controlled across rows/sections?

Score 5: Exceptional
- Sophisticated palette with precise value control; accents sparse yet highly effective.
- Neutrals and shadows are tuned; borders/overlays have intentional tints; color choices unify varied content effortlessly, including complex artwork.
- Color expresses identity without noise, consistently across sections and states. Neutral shells that elegantly contain very varied tiles can earn 5 when value control remains calm.

Score 4: Strong
- Harmonious palette with controlled accents; link/CTA system clearly defined or convincingly implied by consistent usage.
- Neutrals intentionally tuned (off‑black/off‑white) supporting readability and hierarchy; gradients/illustrations sit comfortably within the system.
- Elevated basics acceptable: conservative blue accent can qualify for 4 when mats, borders, and greys are tuned and unify colorful content.
- Minor issues only (one accent slightly hot; a single mismatched gradient; a footer a bit heavy but close; limited state evidence).

Score 3: Competent baseline (default)
- Serviceable palette; neutral shell with a single accent or defaultish link blue used acceptably.
- When colorful tiles carry most color, the chrome does not clash but may lack unifying tactics (few/no mats, borders, or shadow tints).
- Small inconsistencies in accents or value steps, but no major clashes.

Score 2: Below average
- Scattershot accents or competing saturated panels (e.g., large bright color bands) that dominate without purpose.
- Default link blue with thick default underline in an otherwise custom system; inconsistent link/CTA colors; no state logic.
- Value flicker from mixed mats/whites; full‑color logos/tiles not harmonized by the shell; textures or illustrations that spike value and disrupt hierarchy.

Score 1: Poor
- Harsh #000/#fff pairs with no moderation; low‑contrast text; clashing accents; color undermines readability.

Negative indicators that should pull to 2 (or 1 when frequent):
- Uncoordinated bright panels; mismatched pastel/bright mats; inconsistent greys; CTA/link colors detached from the rest of the system; lack of any unifying mats/borders when imagery varies widely.

Gallery/Collage considerations:
- Reward restraint that keeps value calm (consistent mats, caption colors). Penalize ornament (tape/paper textures, stripes) when it distracts from content or breaks value rhythm.

---

typography.explanation: Readable, default‑leaning sans with minimal hierarchy. 1) Nav labels are set in small grey pill buttons with all‑lowercase text; styling is conservative and lacks a distinct typographic voice. 2) Footer copy is very small and light grey, pushing contrast toward low and reducing polish. 3) No captions or text under tiles to demonstrate scale/label systems; link styling and states are not visible beyond the pill buttons. Overall competent but generic with little evidence of tuned rhythm or bespoke micro‑craft.

layout_composition.explanation: Simple centered grid is tidy with even gutters, but image handling weakens composition. 1) Mixed asset types in the same grid (phone‑in‑hand photos, flat logos, desktop/email screenshots, posters) create inconsistent internal mats and rhythm. 2) Several screenshots are unreadable at this size (desktop monitor tile, newsletter tile), reducing the effectiveness of the gallery. 3) Tiles with white backgrounds bleed into the page’s white with no frame/border, causing edge loss and value flicker; others are saturated, so the row rhythm jumps. 4) No captions or consistent placement for labels/CTAs to stabilize alignment. Overall reads like a basic gallery without refinement.

color.explanation: Neutral shell is mostly white, but color control is loose. 1) Bright, varied thumbnail colors sit directly on white without mats, producing strong value flicker across rows. 2) Tiles with pure‑white backgrounds merge with the page while adjacent saturated tiles dominate, reducing cohesion. 3) The logo introduces green and purple accents that are not integrated elsewhere in the UI (nav pills are grey), so accent strategy feels undefined. 4) Footer text is very light grey, bordering on low contrast.

typography.explanation: Minimal on‑page typography: a simple sans serif for the nameplate and nav. 1) Nav shows a basic hierarchy via tone only—'Work' in black vs 'About' in grey—without custom link styling or visible states. 2) Casing is consistent (title case for nav, normal case for name) and spacing around the header feels comfortable. 3) No evident type scale beyond the header; the page lacks a distinctive typographic voice and micro‑craft (no tuned underline, meta styles, or rhythm cues). Limitation: only a single view with very little text, so hierarchy and state consistency can’t be fully assessed.

layout_composition.explanation: A clear, two‑column 2×2 grid with even gutters and generous outer margins shows competent structure. 1) Tiles share consistent aspect and alignment to the grid; header is kept clear of content. 2) Visual weight is uneven—bottom‑left phone crop is very dark and dominates the other three lighter tiles. 3) Internal alignment varies widely (top‑left tile leaves a large left‑biased void, top‑right centers the mark, others use diagonals/symmetry), creating mild rhythm flicker across the row. 4) No framing system (uniform mats/borders) to harmonize mixed imagery. Limitation: only the landing view is visible; no evidence of deeper page structure or responsive behavior.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (white) with a soft grey panel and a pink tile; nothing clashes. 1) Accents come largely from the project imagery rather than a defined site palette. 2) Value balance wobbles—the dark phone tile pulls focus compared to the pale top row. 3) Nav uses neutral greys/black only; there’s no evident accent system or state colors beyond tone. The soft grey is pleasant, but overall color strategy feels ad hoc. Limitation: limited evidence of hover/active states and how color scales across more sections.

typography.explanation: Readable, minimal sans system with clear title/meta hierarchy (bold titles, lighter grey meta). Good details like en dash in dates ("2024–25") and consistent dot separators. Comfortable measure and leading with stable rags. However: 1) Project title casing is inconsistent within the same role (e.g., "Linear Mobile" vs "Interaction prototypes" vs "Linear homepage renders"), which breaks typographic discipline. 2) Link treatment is very understated—nav items look like muted body text with no underline or evident state, reducing affordance. 3) Limited style set with default-leaning voice; little evidence of bespoke link styling or micro‑craft beyond basics. Limitation: only a single simple view is visible, so state behavior and longer text rhythm can't be verified.

layout_composition.explanation: Single-column list is clean and aligned: avatar/name/nav and project list share a common left column; even vertical rhythm between items; consistent spacing between title and meta lines. Generous negative space on the left keeps the column airy and scannable. That said: 1) Structure is generic with no visible POV or inventive grid usage. 2) Interactivity is visually under-signaled (titles and nav read almost like plain text), which softens hierarchy of clickable elements. 3) Evidence limited to one page section—no demonstration of responsive variants, grids, or image handling. Limitation: no screenshots or multi-section composition to assess consistency across modules.

color.explanation: Neutrals appear tuned: off‑white background, charcoal titles, mid‑grey meta provide comfortable contrast; color is used sparingly with the avatar adding a small accent. Values feel controlled with no harsh #000/#fff pairing. However: 1) No clear accent color or state system is visible for links/CTAs, weakening affordance. 2) Nav grey may be a bit low-contrast relative to body roles. 3) With only monochrome text and no diverse assets, there's limited evidence of color unification tactics. Limitation: lack of multiple sections or imagery prevents evaluation of palette handling under stress.

typography.explanation: Clean, disciplined sans system with clear role separation (bold name, lighter handle/meta, regular body in bubbles). Measures within bubbles are short and comfortable with consistent ~1.4–1.6 leading and smooth rags. Links use a custom blue (not default) and appear consistently throughout (inline links, blue CTA bubbles), and top nav uses tidy dot separators that sit well on the baseline. Casing is role‑consistent (sentence case in dialogue, Title Case for project names). No widows/orphans visible and scale steps repeat across bubbles and cards. Limitation: small meta text inside project cards reads a touch light/low‑contrast, and link/hover states are not visible here.

layout_composition.explanation: Distinct conversational layout executed with control: bubbles share consistent corner radii and soft, matched shadows; vertical spacing follows a steady rhythm; and all bubbles align to a single column with ample negative space. The two‑card project block shows equal heights, matching thumbnail aspect ratios and radii, and even internal gutters/caption offsets. Social icon row is contained in equal‑sized tiles with consistent spacing, maintaining the column. Limitation: minor width variation between blue and gray bubbles creates a slightly stepped right edge; the social row sits a bit floaty relative to the preceding caption, and some screenshots are small, limiting evaluability.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals and gentle value control: off‑white background with a subtle cool tint; gray chat bubbles with soft blue shadows; and a single saturated blue used for key messages and links, creating a clear accent system. Shadows appear cool‑tinted, tying elements together. Colorful app thumbnails are contained by neutral cards, preventing value spikes. Limitation: the brand‑colored social icons introduce a bit of palette noise versus the otherwise restrained scheme, and the primary blue runs slightly hot against the very soft neutrals.

typography.explanation: Clear, restrained hierarchy: a small left column of section labels (“About/Notes/Posts/Photos/Contact”) contrasts with a comfortable body size in the right column; date meta (e.g., “Fri, 28 Mar” and “2025 07”) is consistently styled in a lighter tone and smaller size. Body measure sits near an ideal range and leading feels ~1.4–1.6, producing smooth rags in the lists. Links use a custom, non-default treatment with thin underlines and chevron/arrow cues (e.g., “View all posts →”), avoiding default blue. Punctuation and casing are role-consistent, and repeated list items keep identical spacing and baselines. Limitations: the initial “About” paragraph looks slightly long (>~80ch) compared to other blocks; the “Selected work. Let’s build something together” caption reads a bit small/low-contrast; link state/hover isn’t visible here.

layout_composition.explanation: Disciplined two-column grid: narrow label/meta column and wider content column align perfectly across sections. Repetition is strong—notes and posts use the same date column width and baseline rhythm; the four photo thumbnails are equal size with matching gutters and bottoms. The featured image and captions sit neatly within the content column, with consistent margins between sections. No template zigzag or container-width drift is evident; spacing feels based on a stable scale. Limitations: the large hero image’s internal margin feels tighter than the rest of the system, making that row slightly heavier; the guestbook input/button block looks a touch utilitarian and breaks the otherwise typographic rhythm.

color.explanation: Calm, tuned neutrals: off‑black text on a soft white background supports readability without harsh contrast. Accents are restrained—links act as tonal accents with subtle underlines and arrows, letting imagery carry color. The photo row introduces varied hues without causing value flicker thanks to consistent sizing and spacing; overall value control remains even across sections. Limitations: the system is largely monochrome, so affordances rely on subtlety—link emphasis could be slightly underplayed in places; no visible state colors are shown.

typography.explanation: Readable sans system with clear role separation (nav and hero in lowercase; project H2s in Title Case). Link styling appears default: bright blue with standard underline thickness/offset. Hero list uses emoji/colored icons as bullets which create irregular line-height and slightly ragged indents. Outline 'VIEW' pills use all‑caps with slightly loose tracking and a stroke heavier than adjacent text weight. Measures and leading are comfortable but not distinctive. Applied template_scent_high cap: Typography capped at 3.

layout_composition.explanation: Consistent two‑column rhythm: left thumbnail, right copy; spacing feels even and gutters are stable. Additional Work grid maintains a simple two‑column arrangement. However, 'VIEW' buttons fall at different vertical positions per card (dependent on copy length), breaking cross‑row alignment. Thumbnail aspects and heights vary (e.g., dark logo tile vs tall phone collage) introducing baseline drift. Large saturated footer band interrupts the otherwise light layout. Applied template_scent_high cap: Layout capped at 3.

color.explanation: Neutral white shell with a single bright cobalt accent provides adequate contrast. Mixed thumbnail mats (dark charcoal, pastel tan, sky blue, black) cause value flicker across rows. The oversized cobalt footer is very hot relative to the page and dominates the ending section. Greys/neutrals are serviceable but not clearly tuned (reads close to pure black on white).

typography.explanation: Readable sans with clear hierarchy (large H1, section heads like “Experience,” “Toolbox,” “More”). However: 1) Links use a default bright blue with default-ish underline in the Experience section while the footer email is bright blue without underline—mixed, uncustomized link treatment. 2) Body text in the dark Experience band looks small (~12–13px) with tight leading on black, making dense bullet lists. 3) Right-column bullets run fairly long (>~80ch at points), reducing comfort. 4) Minor baseline/spacing tension where bullets sit very close to job meta lines. Overall competent but generic, with link styling and measure/leading holding it back.

layout_composition.explanation: Clear banded sections and a consistent two‑column pattern (left labels, right content). Positive spacing rhythm between major sections. Issues: 1) The centered, colorful scribble mark above the hero pulls attention off-grid and competes with the headline. 2) The large gradient blob on the right is ornamental and competes with the H1’s focal weight. 3) In the dark band, the left label column leaves a large unused field, forcing the right column to a long measure; bullets feel wide. 4) The 'Interested in working together' line with tiny icons sits awkwardly low and the icons don’t align to the text baseline. 5) In the 'More' section, the heading sits alone far left with a large void before the content columns, creating a slightly unbalanced row. Solid but standard structure without refined orchestration.

color.explanation: Neutrals are controlled (white, black, light grey bands) and contrast is strong in the dark section. Weaknesses: 1) Default saturated link blue appears throughout and doesn’t harmonize with the otherwise neutral shell. 2) The hero gradient introduces multiple hues (yellow/green/blue) not echoed elsewhere, reading as a detached accent. 3) The small scribble logo adds yet another hue family (purple/pink), increasing accent count and visual noise. Palette is serviceable but lacks a cohesive accent strategy.

typography.explanation: Readable, minimal sans system with clear section labels (WORK —, PROJECTS —) and consistent en‑dash date ranges. Leading appears comfortable and body copy is tidy. However: 1) the intro paragraph runs quite wide (~85–95ch), making lines long; 2) link styling is not visible—project titles look like plain text with no underline/hue, lowering affordance; 3) hierarchy within each tile is muted—the project name and description are close in size/weight, so levels blur; 4) some meta lines in light grey feel a bit small/low‑contrast compared with body. Overall competent but generic, with few bespoke typographic touches.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is clear: a left intro, a tidy 3‑up 'Work' row, then a consistent 4‑up project grid; gutters are even and alignment to the left column is stable. Positives aside, several issues hold it at baseline: 1) mixed imagery without frames/mats causes value flicker across rows (e.g., bright cyan/yellow tiles next to dark code screens); 2) captions wrap to different line counts, so card bottoms/baselines within rows don't align; 3) thumbnails contain tiny UI that’s unreadable at this size, reducing the effectiveness of the overview; 4) vertical rhythm between the 'Work' strip and 'Projects' label feels a touch tight relative to the generous outer margins. Competent, but no distinctive POV or micro‑orchestration.

color.explanation: Neutral shell (off‑black text, white background, grey dividers/meta) is serviceable and keeps focus on tiles. Yet there’s no clear accent/link system shown, and the gallery lacks unifying color tactics—no consistent mats/borders—so saturated tiles (e.g., bright cyan, teal, yellow) sit next to very dark UI and create noticeable value jumps. The neutrals themselves are fine, but overall color control reads utilitarian, not refined.

typography.explanation: Readable baseline. The hero uses two long paragraphs with comfortable leading (~1.4–1.5) and proper punctuation (em‑dash, italics for emphasis). However, the hero measure appears long (>80ch) which makes the opening line feel breathless. There is little visible hierarchy—no distinct H1 vs body; both hero paragraphs look like the same style/weight. Captions are very small and light grey (~11–12px), pushing contrast to the edge of comfort. Link treatment/states aren’t evident in the screenshot (nav items look like plain text), so system discipline isn’t demonstrated. Overall competent but generic with limited scale steps.

layout_composition.explanation: Two‑column masonry grid with a consistent center gutter (~24–32px) and clean, sharp assets. The first project starts in the right column leaving a large void below the hero, creating perceived width drift from a wide hero block to a staggered grid. Row bottoms do not align—e.g., tall studio photo next to short tiles—producing irregular negative spaces and rhythm flicker. Caption placements vary: some sit tight to the image while others leave larger gaps, and offsets don’t appear to follow a strict spacing system. No unreadable device frames or visible crop errors, but the overall structure reads more collage than disciplined grid.

color.explanation: Chrome is neutral (black/grey text on white) and keeps body copy readable, but there’s little unifying color strategy. Highly saturated tiles sit directly on the page (e.g., a full‑black panel, a bright purple poster, and a large bright yellow panel), creating strong value spikes and noticeable flicker as you scroll. No mats/borders to harmonize diverse artwork, and no evident accent system in the UI (links/CTAs) to tie color together. The result feels jumpy rather than intentionally controlled.

typography.explanation: Clear, restrained system: the hero uses a bold H1 with a custom underline on “Turf” (non‑default hue/weight/offset), and the body copy shows comfortable leading and measure within the card. Labels like “Look around…” and the circular arrow CTAs repeat a small‑caps/label style consistently. Punctuation and spacing feel deliberate (asterisk footnote and inline superscript handled cleanly). Minor rough edges keep it from a 5: link treatments vary (underline in the hero, a pill/button for the tweet, circular arrow chips on tiles), the tweet embed brings a different type style, and some tiny UI text inside device renders is unreadable, weakening typographic cohesion at the tile level.

layout_composition.explanation: The masonry grid shows strong discipline: identical card mats with generous radii, consistent gutters, and repeated placement of the circular arrow affordance in the bottom‑left of tiles. The left hero card anchors the page and aligns to the grid; spacing between cards is even and optical balance is good. Assets are contained within a unifying shell so mixed content (screens, photos, wordmarks) stays coherent. Limitations: some tiles rely on small/angled device shots that are hard to read, the masonry heights create slight rhythm flicker across rows, and the tweet/timeline modules introduce slightly different internal padding and alignment compared to other cards.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals dominate (soft off‑white background, light grey card mats, subtle shadows) providing a calm frame. Accents are controlled—coral/red gradients and brand colors live inside the tiles while the chrome stays neutral, which helps harmonize varied imagery. The active nav pill and micro icons match the soft palette. Minor quibbles: a few bright tiles (e.g., saturated red card, gradient phone mock) spike value more than others and add a touch of flicker; link/CTA accent hues aren’t perfectly unified across all treatments.

typography.explanation: Readable, conservative sans with clear hierarchy (project title, small meta, outline CTA). Meta lines are all‑caps with wide tracking and very light grey, which reduces contrast and feels under‑weighted against the titles. The hero line ('I'm Meredith…') is small and visually timid relative to the rest of the page. Outline button labels use heavier tracking than other caps and feel slightly disconnected from the surrounding type weight. Link styling is not evident beyond buttons, so state logic and underline tuning are unclear. Overall consistent but generic and lightly tuned.

layout_composition.explanation: Simple single‑column list of project rows with consistent left image / right text and thin dividers; spacing rhythm is steady and scan is easy. However, device-frame thumbnails vary (laptop, monitor, phones) creating uneven visual weights and inconsistent vertical centers across rows. Screens are small and largely unreadable inside realistic device renders, weakening the work emphasis. The layout pattern (centered hero + repeated rows with outline CTAs) reads boilerplate and shows little bespoke composition beyond the default template structure.

color.explanation: Neutral, mostly white shell with soft greys for dividers and labels; titles are a dark grey/black. Accents are limited to grey outline buttons. Overall harmony is acceptable but generic. Several meta lines are very light grey, flirting with low contrast. Diverse screenshot colors inside device renders are not unified by mats/borders, producing minor value flicker from row to row.

typography.explanation: Readable, conservative system with a serif display for headings and a sans for body. Positives: hierarchy is clear (hero H1, section H2s, body) and spacing is generally comfortable. Issues holding it to average: (1) The long text block in 'My design wheelhouse' runs wide (~80–90ch), producing loose rags and a slightly tiring read. (2) Reversed text in the black band is small with tight leading (~1.2–1.3), reducing legibility versus the rest of the page. (3) All‑caps outline buttons have letter‑spaced text whose weight and stroke do not match surrounding body weight, reading a bit ‘UI‑kit’ rather than bespoke. (4) Decorative italic/script line 'I look forward to connecting with you' introduces a different voice that doesn’t integrate typographically with other headings. Limitation: link states and finer micro‑details (hover/visited) aren’t visible here.

layout_composition.explanation: A consistent two‑column grid and predictable sectioning keep the page readable. Featured projects repeat the same left‑text/right‑image pattern with even gutters and consistent grey mats. Issues: (1) Device mocks are small and the UI inside phones/laptops is largely unreadable at this scale, weakening the work presentation. (2) Outline CTAs within each project appear at slightly different vertical positions relative to the body copy, creating baseline wobble across rows. (3) Strong banding (white → mint CTA stripe → black section → white) causes rhythm breaks without adding structural clarity. (4) The large team photo band bleeds edge‑to‑edge and feels disconnected from the grid above/below. Limitation: Only one breakpoint is visible; responsive alignment can’t be verified.

color.explanation: Neutral shell with black, white, and a pale mint accent feels pleasant and calm. Grey mats behind screenshots help unify varied imagery. Issues preventing a higher score: (1) Big value jumps between the mint CTA band and the heavy black band introduce noticeable flicker in the page’s rhythm. (2) Screenshot colors are not strongly harmonized; some tiles carry different whites/greys leading to slight value drift across the project list. (3) Outline buttons rely on black strokes on white, reading visually light and not clearly prioritized as actions. Limitation: No visible interactive states to assess accent consistency.

typography.explanation: Measured, readable type with a restrained system. 1) Comfortable measure (~60–70ch) and even leading (~1.5), with clean rags in the body paragraphs. 2) Clear hierarchy: bold H1 ('Benji Taylor'), lighter meta line ('Updated July 8, 2024'), and regular body copy; project rows use consistent label/date styles. 3) Links are treated consistently in blue with an external‑link icon applied uniformly throughout. 4) Spacing between paragraphs and the list is consistent and predictable. Limitations: the link blue reads default and a bit hot; underline/state treatment isn’t evident; the external‑link icon appears slightly low against the x‑height. Evidence is from a single, minimal view.

layout_composition.explanation: Calm, centered single‑column layout executed cleanly. 1) Consistent container width across the page with left‑aligned text; generous margins. 2) The year–title–date rows read as a neat three‑column table with right‑aligned dates and subtle dividers maintaining rhythm. 3) Vertical spacing between header, paragraphs, list, and footer line feels systematic. Limitations: structure is extremely simple and generic; the lone 'Letting time pass…' line floats with no clear grid anchor; no evidence of handling complex imagery or multi‑column compositions.

color.explanation: Neutral palette is controlled and unobtrusive. 1) Off‑white background with near‑black text; meta text in soft grey improves hierarchy. 2) Subtle grey dividers unify the list rows without value spikes. 3) A single blue accent is used consistently for links. Limitations: the blue accent feels default/saturated relative to the otherwise muted neutrals, and no hover/visited state logic is visible; limited evidence due to a text‑only view.

typography.explanation: Section headers use mixed casing within the same role (ABOUT/PORTFOLIO/CONTACT in all caps while 'My Guiding Design Principles' is title case), signaling style inconsistency. The long intro paragraph is center‑aligned, creating uneven rags and reduced readability for a multi‑line block. Body text appears small and light grey, lowering contrast and comfort. Link/label styling in the category filter looks generic with minimal customization and unclear state logic. The overall type system feels like theme defaults with limited hierarchy beyond size changes. Limitation: states/hover and exact font family cannot be verified from the static image.

layout_composition.explanation: Basic structure is clear and scannable with distinct sections and a consistent 4‑column portfolio grid of square thumbnails. However, the page leans heavily on a centered, template‑like structure (headshot hero, grid, contact form) without a distinct POV. Large wave backgrounds create ornamental bands that don’t align to the grid and add visual noise between sections. The filter row sits very close to the grid, making the hierarchy between controls and content tight. Mixed content types in the grid (angled device shots, photos, UI) introduce rhythm variation without harmonizing mats/captions. Applied template_scent_high cap at 3 based on structural cues: centered headshot ‘About’ hero, identical tile grid with category filter, boilerplate contact form, and explicit “Built with GeneratePress” theme credit. Limitation: only one breakpoint visible.

color.explanation: Large pastel wave bands introduce big, saturated color fields that don’t relate to content and create value flicker across sections. The portfolio grid mixes bright photos and UI without neutral mats or borders to unify them, resulting in a busy, noisy impression. Accent logic appears weak (a lone purple 'SEND' button; other links/filters lack a clear accent system). Neutrals for body text skew light, reducing contrast. Limitation: cannot confirm interactive states or exact color values from the screenshot.

typography.explanation: Editorial serif set in large italic gives a distinct voice; lines break cleanly with even leading and no widows across the 6‑line hero. Superscripted years (e.g., “2022–”) and proper en‑dash show attention to detail. Links are customized in a vivid blue rather than default styling; the rest of the paragraph remains a single, disciplined style. Limitations: the measure is long for a display paragraph (~70–80ch), blue links rely on color only (no underline/state visible), and the superscript numerals sit a touch small/loose next to commas (e.g., after “Zip 2022–”).

layout_composition.explanation: Simple, left‑anchored text block with generous negative space feels intentional and balanced. Line lengths are quite long, which slightly stretches the column feel.

color.explanation: Tuned neutrals: a soft, cool grey background and dark slate text create comfortable contrast. Accent strategy is clear—royal blue highlights key links and the small control at top‑right—providing a crisp focal cue without visual noise. Palette is restrained and cohesive. Limitations: the accent blue is a bit hot relative to the muted shell and the top‑right blue control attracts disproportionate attention; no hover/state evidence visible.

typography.explanation: Strong, disciplined type. Observations: 1) Hero uses a heavy sans display with clear scale steps vs body (~3–4x), tight but controlled tracking; the four single-word lines create an unmistakable hierarchy. 2) Section titles 'Selected Projects' and 'Latest Articles' appear as large, low-contrast background type in consistent Title Case; meta labels like '01/02/03' and project titles repeat a clear small-label style. 3) Article excerpts sit in comfortable measures (~55–65ch) with ~1.4–1.6 leading; 'Read more →' links are customized (non-default hue, arrow glyph, no default blue underline) and treated consistently. 4) Off-black body text and subtle weight changes provide hierarchy without over-bolding. Limitation: the hero display weight is very dense and slightly tight; the oversized background words are cropped at section edges, which introduces minor typographic tension.

layout_composition.explanation: Well-orchestrated structure with a clear grid. Observations: 1) Left-aligned hero stack balanced by a right portrait card; consistent gutters and a soft horizontal band transition into the work section. 2) Project tiles share consistent card widths, shadow logic, and numbered captions (01–03) that align, signaling a disciplined system. 3) The article grid repeats spacing and caption positions across three columns; 'Read more' links align to the text blocks. 4) Visual rhythm is reinforced by the large background section titles while content cards stay on-grid. Limitations: the 'View All' pill sits somewhat floaty in the top-right of sections without a clearly visible column tie; internal imagery across project tiles varies (phone mock vs white document vs tablet) causing slight value rhythm flicker; the giant background words overlap into card areas, adding minor visual busyness.

color.explanation: Calm, tuned neutrals with restrained accents. Observations: 1) Off-white background, soft grey section band, and subtle shadows keep value steps controlled—no harsh #000/#fff pairs. 2) Accents are minimal and role-clear (neutral 'View All' pill, black arrows for links), allowing the work imagery to carry color. 3) The portrait’s teal and the bright white document in a tile are contained by neutral mats and shadows so they don’t dominate. Limitation: mixed thumbnail internals (dark phone UI vs bright white doc vs tablet) introduce light value flicker across the project row; large pale section titles occasionally compete slightly with nearby controls.

typography.explanation: Readable, bold sans system with clear hierarchy and a consistent bright-blue link style. Positives: micro-labels (e.g., 'Companies I’ve collaborated with') are sized and toned well; the in-text link 'Framer' is styled consistently; arrows appear baseline-aligned. Issues keeping it at 3: display lines are quite heavy and tight (hero lines feel compressed with minimal leading), the CTA 'Lets connect' is missing an apostrophe (punctuation/grammar error), and the large display scale vs. small body creates a steep jump that reads a bit shouty. Link treatment relies on color without underline or hover evidence, and overall voice feels default (likely Inter) rather than bespoke.

layout_composition.explanation: Structure is coherent with consistent container widths and generous spacing.
